title: 106_s2761
content: The Act may be cited as the "Capturing Criminals Act of 2000" and includes provisions for Fugitive Apprehension Task Forces. The Attorney General can establish Fugitive Apprehension Task Forces with a budget of $20 million for 2001, $5 million for 2002, and $5 million for 2003 to locate and apprehend fugitives. This does not limit other Federal or State law authorities. The authority to establish Fugitive Apprehension Task Forces with a budget does not limit the authority under any other provision of Federal or State law to locate or apprehend a fugitive. SEC. 3. ADMINISTRATIVE SUBPOENAS TO APPREHEND FUGITIVES. Chapter 49 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include administrative subpoenas to apprehend fugitives defined as individuals accused or convicted of committing a felony under Federal or State law and fleeing from the jurisdiction of the court. The amended Chapter 49 of title 18, United States Code allows for administrative subpoenas to apprehend fugitives accused or convicted of committing a felony and fleeing from court jurisdiction. The term 'investigation' refers to cases where fugitives evade the court's jurisdiction or escape custody using interstate or foreign commerce facilities. The Attorney General may subpoena witnesses and request assistance from law enforcement officers in investigations involving fugitives accused of felonies fleeing court jurisdiction. The term 'State' includes states, the District of Columbia, and U.S. territories. The Attorney General can subpoena witnesses and request assistance from law enforcement officers in investigations of fugitives accused of felonies. Subpoenas must describe the required records, specify a return date, and can be served by any designated person. Witnesses may be required to appear within 500 miles and will be paid fees and mileage. Service of a subpoena can be done by personal delivery or certified mail to a natural person, or by delivering it to an authorized agent of a corporation or association. The affidavit of service by the agent is proof of compliance. The Attorney General can seek court assistance for noncompliance with a subpoena. The court has jurisdiction to compel compliance with a subpoena, and failure to obey may result in contempt charges. The subpoena recipient has rights to challenge the subpoena in court within 20 days of service. A person can file a petition in the district court to modify or quash a subpoena if they believe it is unreasonable, fails to meet requirements, or violates rights. The time for compliance with the subpoena is suspended during the petition process. The Attorney General can delay notification to subscribers or customers when issuing administrative subpoenas to electronic communication or remote computing service providers. They can also seek court orders to prevent notification to other parties. The Attorney General can apply for court orders to delay customer notice and require nondisclosure when issuing subpoenas for financial records. The administrative subpoena can result in endangering individuals, flight from prosecution, evidence tampering, witness intimidation, or jeopardizing an investigation. Those who produce records in good faith are immune from civil liability. The Attorney General and the Secretary can delegate authority. The Attorney General and the Secretary of the Treasury will issue guidelines for administrative subpoenas, requiring approval from senior supervisory personnel. The Attorney General must report annually to Congress on the number of subpoenas issued, agencies involved, and charges imposed. Reporting requirement ends after 3 years. SEC. 4. STUDY AND REPORT OF THE USE OF ADMINISTRATIVE SUBPOENAS. The Attorney General must complete a study on administrative subpoena power by executive branch agencies by December 31, 2001. The report to Congress should include sources of subpoena power, enforcement mechanisms, privacy safeguards, issuance standards, and recommendations for ensuring proper use of administrative subpoenas. The Attorney General must study administrative subpoena power by executive branch agencies by December 31, 2001, including enforcement mechanisms, privacy safeguards, and recommendations for proper use.
